did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

origination.label: Creator
origination.persname: Cabanis, P. J. G. (Pierre Jean Georges), 1757-1808

did.unittitle: Pierre Jean Georges Cabanis letter, Auteuil, near Paris, to "Citoyen Maine-Biran."
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Letter (ALS). In this very cordial letter, apparently written to Maine de Biran after his exclusion from the Council of Five Hundred on suspicion of royalism, Cabanis, himself a member of the Council, admonishes him to continue with his work, promising him every assistence.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the Rubenstein to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Pierre Jean Georges Cabanis Letter, 1803, Feb. [5 or 6], Auteuil, near Paris, to "Citoyen Maine-Biran.", David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding aid derived from MARC record, October 2014

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: French physician, physiologist and materialist philosopher.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letter (ALS). In this very cordial letter, apparently written to Maine de Biran after his exclusion from the Council of Five Hundred on suspicion of royalism, Cabanis, himself a member of the Council, admonishes him to continue with his work, promising him every assistence.

note.label: General note
note.p: Forms part of the Trent Manuscripts Collection.
